Utilizing water as an electron donor for the artificial CO2 photoreduction into valuable chemicals presents a promising way to partially address energy challenges and achieve carbon neutrality. Syngas (CO and H2) is an ideal platform for synthesizing hydrocarbons and carbonyl compounds, etc., and it can be synthesized from CO2 reduction. Recently, photothermal catalysis combines the advantages of photocatalysis and thermal catalysis, which is a promising approach to achieving the reaction under relatively mild conditions. In the present work, a catalyst, comprised of titanate nanosheets (TiNS) and BiOBr (BOB), was feasibly prepared and used for photothermal CO2 reduction, in which water serves as the electron donor. The catalyst delivered CO and H2 yields of 168 μmol·gcat −1·h−1 and 219 μmol·gcat −1·h−1. Notably, the CO yield is 9 times higher than TiNS and 3 times higher than BiOBr alone. Experimental studies and theoretical calculations indicated that the introduction of oxygen vacancies in TiNS significantly provided more active sites for the adsorption and activation of CO2, while also reducing the energy barrier of the rate-determining step in the CO2-to-CO reduction. Typically, the 50 wt% BOB/TiNS catalyst exhibited strong adsorption and activation of CO2 and showed a low barrier for the rate-determining step in the titled reduction. Consequently, the photothermal catalytic CO2 conversion performance was significantly improved, offering a rational design concept for the photothermal catalytic CO2 reduction to produce syngas. Graphical abstract A catalyst containing titanate nanosheets (TiNS) and BiOBr (BOB) was easily fabricated for effective photothermal CO2 reduction. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Photothermal catalysis CO2 reduction BiOBr/TiNS heterostructures Oxygen vacancy Syngas Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The CO2 concentration in the atmosphere has increased dramatically in the last several decades. The conversion of CO2 into value-added chemicals, such as CO, CH4, and CH3OH, is recognized as a green carbon-neutral technology for future renewable energy [1]. Among the various products of CO2 photoreduction, syngas (CO and H2) is considered a common platform via CO hydrogenation, hydroformylation, and Fischer-Tropsch synthesis reaction for important chemical industries such as alcohols, aldehydes, and hydrocarbons [2]. Syngas has a wide range of applications, especially in manufacturing various industrial products. However, these different products have different requirements for the H₂/CO ratio in syngas. When the H₂/CO ratio is greater than or equal to 2/1, it is suitable for the production of methanol and light olefins (C2–4). If the ratio is less than or equal to 2/1, it can be used for the production of wax and diesel. When the ratio is 1.5/1, it can be used to produce aldehydes and higher alcohols. If the ratio is 1/1, it can be used to produce aldehydes, higher alcohols, dimethyl ether, oxygenated alcohols, and acetic acid. When the ratio is 1/2, it can be used to produce polycarbonate [3,4]. However, this promising approach is often hampered by difficult CO2 activation, slow reaction kinetics, and complex selectivity [5,6]. Therefore, there is an urgent need to develop suitable photocatalysts that can stimulate the targeted reduction of CO2 to syngas [7], which mainly depends on the photoredox performance of the catalyst [8]. Thus, achieving simultaneous and efficient syngas production remains challenging. Compared with photocatalysis, traditional thermal catalysis requires harsh conditions, such as high temperatures and pressures. Therefore, to reduce the reaction temperature in thermal catalytic reactions and improve the catalytic activity of photocatalytic reactions, photothermal catalytic technology was proposed recently. Photothermal catalysis not only efficiently utilizes solar energy but also reduces energy consumption. It combines the advantages of photocatalysis and thermal catalysis, enabling excellent catalytic activity under mild conditions [9]. So far, an array of catalysts including CoOCuO/TiO2 CeO2[10], (Ni, Fe)-N-C[11], Bi2S3/CdXZn1-XS[12], Bi2S3/UiO-66[13], Bi4TaO8Cl/W18O49[14], TiO2/UiO-66[15], AgBr/BiOBr[16], and TTCOF-Zn[17] have been developed and applied in photocatalytic or photothermal catalytic CO2 reduction reaction (CRR), with detailed catalytic properties shown in Table S1. TiO2 is extensively utilized for photocatalytic CO2 reduction owing to its comparatively negative reduction potential, high physicochemical stability, adjustable energy band structure, non-toxicity, and other characteristics.[18] Nevertheless, the inherent drawbacks of its excessively wide forbidden bandwidth and high photogenerated electron-hole recombination rate significantly impede its catalytic efficiency. Consequently, to enhance the visible light utilization rate of semiconductors like TiO2, various modifications are commonly employed, such as heterojunction construction, precious metal deposition, defect introduction, crystal surface control, surface function modification, and morphology design. These modifications can suppress the photogenerated electron-hole recombination, thereby improving the catalytic activity [19]. Bismuth oxyhalides (BiOX, X=Br, Cl, and I), as commonly applied photocatalysts, have been widely studied for their excellent photocatalytic activity in many aspects [20]. In particular, their application in artificial CO2 conversion has attracted much attention in recent years [21]. However, the original BiOX had low separation efficiency and photoreduction capacity, limited active sites, and poor performance in photocatalytic CO2 reduction [22]. In the present work, we reported a BiOBr/TiNS composite catalyst with high efficiency in photothermal catalytic CO2 conversion, prepared by a simple coprecipitation method. The catalytic performance was tested without adding photosensitizers or sacrificial agents, and the reduction products were qualitatively analyzed. The results showed that adding the constructed oxygen vacancy-rich TiNS increases the oxygen vacancy and adsorbed oxygen in the BOB/TiNS heterojunction, leading to high CO2 photothermal reduction efficiency. 2 Experimental section Information on used materials and methods for material characterization, photochemical measurements, in-situ DRIFTS, and DFT calculations can be found in the supporting information. 2.1 Synthesis of TiNS TiNS were prepared based on the reported literatures with suitable modifications [23–25]. First, a mixture of TiO2 and Cs2CO3 with a certain dosage ratio was calcined at 800 °C by solid phase grinding method to prepare the precursor cesium titanate and then reacted in 100 mL HCl (1 mol/L) solution for 4 days, and replaced with a new HCl solution every day. The cesium in the precursor cesium titanate was proton exchanged, and the protonated titanate nanosheets were obtained. The layered titanate lattice was peeled off after adding tetrabutylammonium hydroxide and embedding in titanate proton for >10 days. After the reaction, the mixture was centrifuged at 7000 r/min for 3 min under high-speed centrifugation and washed with water >5 times to remove excess tetrabutylammonium hydroxide and incompletely stripped particles. 2.2 Synthesis of BiObr/TiNS A coprecipitation method was used to prepare the BiOBr/TiNS composite catalyst [26]. Taking 50 wt% BiOBr/TiNS catalyst as an example, the preparation steps are as follows: Bi(NO3)3·5H2O (0.485 g, 1 mmol) was dissolved in 100 mL of 1.4 M acetic acid solution under agitation to obtain solution A. KBr (0.352 g, 2 mmol) and TiNS (0.2 g) were dissolved in 100 mL deionized water under stirring, then ultrasounded for 10 min (solution B). After that, solution A was added to solution B drop by drop under continuously stirring for 4 h, and then aged for 1 h. The obtained precipitate was washed and centrifuged >5 times and dried at 60 °C for 12 h to obtain the 50 wt% BiOBr/TiNS catalyst. The catalysts such as 40 wt% BiOBr/TiNS, 45 wt% BiOBr/TiNS, 55 wt% BiOBr/TiNS, and 60 wt% BiOBr/TiNS were prepared by the same method. The preparation processes of pure BiOBr are similar to the aforementioned procedures, but no TiNS was added. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Catalyst characterization The microstructure and composition of the pure BiOBr, TiNS, and 50 wt% BiOBr/TiNS catalysts were studied using SEM, TEM, HRTEM, and EDX, respectively. The SEM (Figs. 1 a and S1b) and TEM (Figs. 1d and 2 a) images of the pure BiOBr catalyst show a smooth surface lamellar structure. The SEM (Figs. 1b and S1a) and TEM (Figs. 1e and S2b) images of the pure TiNS sample exhibit that it consists of particles with a relatively uniform size. SEM images indicate that TiNS particles are successfully recombined on the BiOBr film, as also evident from the TEM image of Fig. 1f. The HRTEM images of the 50 wt% BiOBr/TiNS catalyst show clear lattice fringes (Fig. 1g–i), with lattice spacings of 0.3265 nm and 0.2742 nm, which correspond well to the (110) crystal planes of TiNS and BiOBr, respectively. The above-mentioned characterization results confirm that the TiNS and BiOBr composite catalyst was successfully prepared. The EDS element mapping of the 50 wt% BiOBr/TiNS catalyst (Fig. 1j) verifies the uniform distribution of Bi, Br, Ti, and O elements in the specified region, further proving the coexistence of TiNS and BiOBr in the composite. As shown in Fig. 2a, the XRD patterns of pure BiOBr, TiNS, and x wt% BiOBr/TiNS, along with the standard PDF cards of BiOBr and TiNS, were used to determine the composition and crystallinity of the catalysts. For the XRD pattern of pure BiOBr, peaks at 11.0, 22.0, 25.3, 31.7, 32.2, 39.4, 46.2, 50.7, and 57.1° correspond to the (001), (002), (101), (102), (110), (112), (200), (104), and (212) crystal planes of BiOBr (JCPDS No. 03–0393), respectively. The XRD pattern of TiNS also matches precisely with the PDF card of TiO2 (JCPDS No. 21–1276). These results indicate that highly crystalline BiOBr, TiNS, and their x wt% BiOBr/TiNS composite heterojunction catalysts have been successfully synthesized[27]. From the enlarged Figure, it can be observed that the peak of the BiOBr/TiNS composite catalyst, with BiOBr (002) as the index, is slightly shifted to the lower angle, suggesting an interaction occurrence between BiOBr and TiNS. No significant peak shift was observed in BiOBr/TiNS catalysts. As shown in Fig. 2c, compared with the original BiOBr and TiNS, strong peaks of both BiOBr and TiNS appear obviously in the composite heterojunction catalyst. It can be seen from Fig. 2c that with increasing BiOBr content, the diffraction peak intensity of BiOBr increases, while the diffraction peak intensity of TiNS decreases correspondingly. Simultaneously, no other impurity peaks were detected in the XRD pattern of the x wt% BiOBr/TiNS series composite heterojunction, indicating that almost no other impurities were produced during the preparation of the samples.[28] The Raman spectra of BiOBr, TiNS, and the 50 wt% BiOBr/TiNS composite are shown in Fig. 3 a. The pure BiOBr exhibits an obvious peak at 114 cm−1 and a weak peak at 161 cm−1 in the Bi-Br stretching mode, corresponding to the A1 g and Eg, respectively [29,30]. For TiNS, there are three distinct signals at 140, 440, and 610 cm−1, which are associated with the B1 g, Eg, and A1 g modes of the rutile TiO2 lattice, respectively. A broad peak at 234 cm−1 is attributed to significant lattice disorder and multiple scattering levels in the redstone [31]. The textural properties of the samples, including specific surface area and pore characteristics, were determined using the N₂ adsorption-desorption method. The N₂ adsorption-desorption isotherms for BiOBr, TiNS, and 50 wt% BiOBr/TiNS are presented in Fig. 3b, while the analysis results for the pore information and BET surface area are detailed in Table S2. All samples exhibited type IV isotherms with H₃ hysteresis loops, indicative of a mesoporous structure.[32] In general, the samples displayed similar BET-specific surface areas. The lower surface area observed in certain samples suggests that changes in catalytic performance are less influenced by surface area, implying that mass transfer limitations may not be the primary factor affecting the reaction. To further confirm the adsorption capacity of the catalyst for CO₂, the isothermal adsorption of CO₂ was recorded at 0 °C (Fig. 3c). It can be seen that TiNS has a slightly higher CO₂ adsorption capacity, and the addition of TiNS increases the CO2 adsorption capacity of the BiOBr/TiNS composite catalyst. However, the overall change is minor. Different catalysts’ surface elemental content and chemical state were determined using XPS. As the full XPS spectrum shown in Fig. 4 a, Bi, O, Br, and Ti elements are detected in the 50 wt% BiOBr/TiNS catalyst. Fig. 4b presents the C 1s spectrum, where the peak at 284.8 eV can be attributed to the CC bond. Peaks at 286.3 and 288.7 eV are characteristic of C−O and C=O, respectively [33]. By correcting the binding energy of the C 1s at 284.8 eV, the high-resolution spectra for other elements were obtained. In Fig. 4c, the Bi 4f spectrum of the BiOBr catalyst shows characteristic peaks at 159.14 and 164.44 eV, corresponding to Bi3+ 4f7/2 and 4f5/2 XPS peaks [34]. As shown in Fig. 4d, there are obvious peaks at 68.18 and 69.25 eV, corresponding to Br 3d5/2 and Br 3d2/3, respectively [35]. The XPS spectrum of Ti 2p is presented in Fig. 4e. For individual TiNS, the Ti 2p3/2 and Ti 2p1/2 peaks are located at 458.43 and 464.72 eV, respectively, indicating the presence of Ti4+, the broadening of the peak at Ti 2p1/2 for the 50 wt% BiOBr/TiNS catalyst was attributed to the overlap with the Bi 4d5/2 peak. In addition, Fig. 4f is the XPS spectrum of O 1s. Three different peaks of O 1s are lattice oxygen (Bi-O) peak (OL), oxygen vacancy peak (OV), and adsorbed oxygen ion peak (Oobs), which are located at 529.47, 531.78, and 533.30 eV, respectively [36]. In particular, compared with commercial P25, which is not calcined and stripped, the oxygen vacancy and the peak of adsorbed oxygen in TiNS are significantly enhanced, increasing the OV in the BiOBr/TiNS heterojunction and thus improving the catalytic efficiency, the utilization of the Cs₂CO₃ component not only facilitates easy removal but also promotes the formation of oxygen vacancies. The higher O 1s binding energy in the 50 wt% BiOBr/TiNS catalyst compared to the pure TiNS also verifies the interaction between TiNS and BiOBr. Moreover, in the 50 wt% BiOBr/TiNS catalyst, the Ti 2p peak is also blue-shifted compared to TiNS, while Bi 4f and Br 3d peaks have lower binding energy shifts compared with BiOBr. These peak shifts indicate electrons are transferred from TiNS to BiOBr, resulting in a higher electron density on BiOBr and a lower electron density on TiNS at the interface between BiOBr and TiNS. The results demonstrate that the addition of BiOBr and TiNS forms a heterojunction. No other elements including Cs were detected from the XPS full spectrum. 3.2 Catalytic performances The photothermal catalytic performance of CO2 reduction was studied in aqueous media under irradiation by a 300 W xenon lamp at 140 °C. Initially, various catalysts were screened to evaluate their activities, and the results are summarized in Table 1 . No product was detected without a catalyst (entry 1). Among these tested catalysts, the photothermal catalytic performances over the pure TiNS, P25, and BiOBr are poor, due to their weak responses to visible light and the rapid recombination of charge carriers (entries 2–4). The combination of BiOBr and TiNS showed significantly enhanced performance, with CO and H2 activities of 168 and 219 μmol·gcat −1·h−1, respectively (entry 5). As can be seen from Table 1 (entries 5–8), compared with other BiOX/TiNS, BiOBr/TiNS can improve the yield while keeping the H2 yield relatively stable, thus making the H2/CO ratio close to 1.5:1, creating favorable conditions for the subsequent production of aldehydes and higher alcohols. Notably, no other carbon-containing products including CH4, CH3OH, or HCOOH were produced over the present catalyst system, as confirmed by the 1H NMR spectrum in Fig. S3. After constructing BiOBr/TiNS heterostructure, the production of CO and H2 was significantly increased, and the tight BiOBr/TiNS interface facilitated the separation of photogenerated carriers [37]. Besides, compared with the reported catalysts recently in Table S1, the present catalyst showed high performances under the similar conditions, indicating its priority. Then, the activity of the BiOBr/TiNS heterojunctions with different BiOBr contents was tested, as shown in Fig. 5 a. The 50 wt% BiOBr/TiNS catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic performance, achieving CO and H2 yields of 168 and 219 μmol·gcat −1·h−1, respectively. These yields were almost 9 times and 1.5 times higher than pure TiNS. Excessive BiOBr can reduce the effective contact between TiNS and BiOBr, thereby decreasing the migration and separation efficiency of photogenerated carriers and thus lowering the photothermal catalytic activity. Conversely, when the BiOBr content is too low, it is insufficient to form an adequate heterojunction interface to promote the separation of photogenerated carriers [38]. These results demonstrate that heterojunction can effectively enhance the photocatalytic performance. Control experiments were conducted to investigate the effect of reaction conditions on the catalytic performance. Fig. 5b shows the influence of temperature on catalytic performance over the 50 wt% BiOBr/TiNS catalyst. The results indicated that temperature significantly affects catalytic activity. The product yields were lower at 80 °C and 100 °C reaction temperatures. At 120 °C, the catalytic performance significantly increased, and at 140 °C, the CO and H2 yields increased sharply. A slight further increase was observed at 160 °C. Considering both reaction temperature and optimal catalytic activity, 140 °C was selected as the optimal temperature for the 50 wt% BiOBr/TiNS catalyst. The effect of reaction time on the photothermal catalytic performance over the 50 wt% BiOBr/TiNS catalyst was investigated, with the results shown in Fig. 5c. In the first hour, the yields of CO and H2 reached 168 and 219 μmol·gcat −1, respectively. As the reaction time extended, the yield of each product increased significantly. However, considering the time efficiency, 1 hour was chosen as the best reaction time. As a reducing agent, water is essential in the reaction, and its effect on the activity is shown in Fig. 5d. The highest CO production was observed at 7 mL of water, indicating that the reaction reached equilibrium under the given conditions. Insufficient water does not provide enough active H+, an appropriate amount of water can serve as an electron donor, promoting an increase in the CO production rate. However, when there is an excessive amount of water, the hydrogen evolution reaction becomes extremely intense, thus inhibiting the formation of CO. Both insufficient and excessive water volumes can negatively impact the reaction. As shown in Fig. 5e, the reusability of the catalyst was tested under the same reaction conditions. The 50 wt% BiOBr/TiNS catalyst maintained stable photothermal CO2 reduction activity in the four cycles, especially for the CO and H2 productions, it kept >90 % of the initial activity, reflecting the stability of the catalyst in the reaction. By comparing the XRD patterns of the catalyst and the new catalyst, it was found that the crystal structures of the two are highly consistent. (Fig. 5f). 3.3 Roles of photo and thermal conditions To clarify the specific contribution of light and thermal conditions, we analyzed the catalytic activity of the 50 wt% BiOBr/TiNS catalyst under light, heat, and photothermal conditions, with results shown in Fig. 6 a. Under the pure heat condition, a trace amount of product formation was detected, while under the sole light without external heating, a CO yield of 14 μmol·gcat −1·h−1 was detected. Under photothermal conditions, the CO and H2 yields are significantly increased, and the CO yield can be increased by approximately 7.3 times compared with that under pure light. These results revealed that photothermal synergistic catalysis promotes CO2 conversion into CO. Negligible CO2 reduction products were observed in the argon (Ar) atmosphere or without a catalyst, which confirmed that CO was generated from CO2. 13CO2 isotope labeling experiment in Fig. S4 further indicated that the CO product was derived from reducing CO2 rather than other substituting carbon sources. In photocatalysis, electrons or holes excited under light irradiation can achieve reduction or oxidation reactions [39,40]. Photothermal catalysis is much more complex than individual photocatalysis and thermal catalysis [41]. Three mechanisms are typically involved in photothermal catalysis: photo-assisted thermal catalysis, thermo-assisted photocatalysis, and photothermal cocatalysis [42]. To investigate the influence of excited electrons and holes on the reaction, PX (p-xylene) was added as the sacrificial electron donor and triethanolamine (TEA) as the sacrificial hole scavenger under light and heat conditions,[43] and two comparative experiments were conducted. As shown in Fig. 6b, the activity with adding TEA was higher than without a sacrifice agent, indicating that hole scavenger can effectively inhibit the recombination of photogenerated electrons and holes. The activity decreased in the presence of PX, indicating that the trapped electrons can prevent the transfer of electrons to the catalyst surface to participate in the CO2 reduction reaction. The results show that electrons and holes play an important role in the photothermal reduction of CO2. In conjunction with Fig. 6a, there is no CO production under the pure thermal condition, thus it is reasonable to infer that the reaction was carried out through the heat-assisted photocatalysis (TAPC) pathway. This suggests that the photoelectronic properties of the samples will affect the catalytic performances remarkably. 3.4 Photoelectrochemical properties of the samples To evaluate the enhancement of their photocatalytic performance, we calculated the band energies of BiOBr, TiNS, and 50 wt% BiOBr/TiNS. The visible light absorption capacity of the sample was studied by using UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (Fig. 7 a). The absorption edge of TiNS is approximately 441 nm, indicating specific absorption in the visible range. With the addition of BiOBr, the absorption edge of 50 wt% BiOBr/TiNS appears redshifted in the visible light range. Therefore, the introduction of BiOBr helps to broaden the visible light response range of TiNS. The range and intensity of light absorption directly influence photocatalytic activity. Consequently, the addition of BiOBr significantly improves the photocatalytic activity of TiNS. The band gaps (Eg) of BiOBr and TiNS were calculated using the Kubelka-Munk formula [44], i.e., αhν = A (hν-Eg) n/2 . According to Fig. 7a, the band gaps of BiOBr and TiNS are 2.63 and 2.98 eV, respectively. As shown in Fig. 7b and c, the obtained BiOBr and TiNS curves have a positive slope, indicating that BiOBr and TiNS are n-type semiconductors [45]. The flat band potentials (EFB) of BiOBr and TiNS are −0.74 and −0.88 V (vs. Ag/AgCl), respectively. BiOBr and TiNS are n-type semiconductors whose flat-charge potentials are close to the conduction band (ECB) positions [46]. Adjusted for EAg/AgCl (0.197 V)[47], the ECB for BiOBr and TiNS are −0.68 and −0.54 V(vs. NHE), respectively. Combining the corresponding band gaps and conduction band values, the valence bands (EVB) of BiOBr and TiNS, calculated by the formula EVB = ECB+Eg,[48] are 3.31 and 3.52 V, respectively. Transient photocurrent signals (I-t) and EIS measurements of BiOBr, TiNS, and 50 wt% BiOBt/TiNS were conducted to investigate the migration resistance and response of the photoinduced carriers. The I-t curves, as shown in Fig. 7d, reveal that the photocurrent density of 50 wt% BiOBr/TiNS is significantly higher than that of BiOBr and TiNS alone, suggesting that the photoinduced carrier has a higher separation efficiency under visible light [49]. As shown in Fig. 7e, the EIS radius of the 50 wt% BiOBr/TiNS catalyst is much smaller than that of BiOBr and TiNS, indicating lower charge transfer resistance. The relative potentials of TiNS and BiOBr and the possible charge transfer pathways for photothermal CO2 reduction by BiOBr/TiNS composites are shown in Fig. 7f. When TiNS and BiOBr come into contact with each other, electrons in TiNS spontaneously transfer to BiOBr due to their different Fermi energy levels, a phenomenon verified by XPS spectroscopy. When TiNS and BiOBr are excited, electrons on the valence band (VB) are excited onto the conduction band (CB), leaving holes in the VB. The photoelectrons at CB of TiNS were successfully transferred to the holes at BiOBr through the interface while maintaining a strong redox capacity [50]. The results confirmed the formation of a Z-scheme heterojunction at the interface between BiOBr and TiNS. This charge transfer mechanism not only optimizes the redox capacity of the two semiconductors but also minimizes recombination and increases the lifetime of photogenerated carriers, thereby greatly improving the effectiveness of photocatalytic CO2 reduction in the 50 wt% BiOBr/TiNS heterojunction. 3.5 Catalytic mechanism To further understand the CO2 reduction process on the surface of 50 wt% BiOBr/TiNS, we studied the involved intermediates in photothermal CO2 reduction using in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS). Fig. 8 a shows the in-situ DRIFTS spectra of 50 wt% BiOBr/TiNS at different exposure time under light irradiation. Characteristic peaks for *COO (929 cm−1), bidentate carbonate (b-CO3 2−, 1353 cm−1), monodentate carbonate (m-CO3 2−, 1319 and 1450–1490 cm−1), and *COOH (1550 cm−1) can be found [51]. These peaks represent the essential intermediates in the CO2 reduction process. Additionally, gaseous CO (2076 cm−1) and H2O (1637 cm−1) are also detected, and their intensities gradually increase with prolonged exposure to light irradiation [52]. Based on the above related DRIFTS results, we proposed a possible pathway for the photothermal CO2 reduction over the 50 wt% BiOBr/TiNS heterojunction, in which CO2 could be transferred to CO via a CO2 →*CO2 →*COOH →*CO →CO pathway [53]. To verify the mechanism for photothermal CO2 reduction over BiOBr/TiNS, key intermediates and potential energy curves were computed by density functional theory (DFT) calculations. For comparison, individual BiOBr and TiNS were also studied. The results are shown in Fig. 8b and c. Based on in-situ DRIFTS and DFT calculations, the formation of CO over the present catalysts through the following steps. Initially, CO2 is activated by oxygen vacancy to form *CO2 (step 1), which then reacts with H + and an e − to form the *COOH intermediate, conformed by in-situ DRIFTS (Step 2). The *COOH can be reduced to *CO (Step 3), followed by release from the catalyst to form CO. In the entire CO2-to-CO conversion process, the protonation of *CO2 to *COOH is considered the rate-determining step [54,55]. The Gibbs free energy (ΔG) for this step over the 50 wt% BiOBr/TiNS catalyst is significantly lower than that on BiOBr and TiNS, indicating that the 50 wt% BiOBr/TiNS catalyst significantly enhances the activation of CO2. The excellent performance of BiOBr/TiNS-catalyzed photothermal CO2 reduction can be attributed to the following points. Firstly, the introduction of TiNS significantly increases the amounts of oxygen vacancies in heterojunctions, thus providing more active sites [56]. Secondly, the close interconnection between BiOBr and TiNS enhances the synergistic effect. Thirdly, the photogenerated electrons in the TiNS conduction band are effectively separated from the photogenerated holes and transferred to the BiOBr valence band, which improves the carrier utilization rate. 4 Conclusions In summary, a 50 wt% BiOBr/TiNS composite photothermal catalyst was prepared using a simple coprecipitation method. The TiNS component showed a significant number of oxygen vacancies compared to commercial P25, a type of TiO2, which not only increased the active sites of the catalyst but also significantly boosted its catalytic efficiency in the photothermal reduction of CO2 and H2O to CO and H2. DFT calculations revealed that the BiOBr/TiNS composite possesses superior adsorption and activation capabilities for CO2 molecules, effectively lowering the energy barrier of the rate-determining step in the CO2 reduction process to CO, further enhancing the CO2 conversion efficiency in photothermal catalysis. In addition, the composite facilitates efficient separation and transfer of photocarriers, offering a more efficient approach for photothermal/photoelectric CO2 reduction to syngas in an aqueous medium. coredata.dc:description: Utilizing water as an electron donor for the artificial CO2 photoreduction into valuable chemicals presents a promising way to partially address energy challenges and achieve carbon neutrality. Syngas (CO and H2) is an ideal platform for synthesizing hydrocarbons and carbonyl compounds, etc., and it can be synthesized from CO2 reduction. Recently, photothermal catalysis combines the advantages of photocatalysis and thermal catalysis, which is a promising approach to achieving the reaction under relatively mild conditions. In the present work, a catalyst, comprised of titanate nanosheets (TiNS) and BiOBr (BOB), was feasibly prepared and used for photothermal CO2 reduction, in which water serves as the electron donor. The catalyst delivered CO and H2 yields of 168 μmol·gcat −1·h−1 and 219 μmol·gcat −1·h−1. Notably, the CO yield is 9 times higher than TiNS and 3 times higher than BiOBr alone. Experimental studies and theoretical calculations indicated that the introduction of oxygen vacancies in TiNS significantly provided more active sites for the adsorption and activation of CO2, while also reducing the energy barrier of the rate-determining step in the CO2-to-CO reduction. Typically, the 50 wt% BOB/TiNS catalyst exhibited strong adsorption and activation of CO2 and showed a low barrier for the rate-determining step in the titled reduction. Consequently, the photothermal catalytic CO2 conversion performance was significantly improved, offering a rational design concept for the photothermal catalytic CO2 reduction to produce syngas.
